item.title: #114 On-the-fly fix of broken songs
item.detail: Hi! Background: Thank you for a great work with ultrastar! I have a vast ultrastar song archive and also normally a very large audience when running ultrastar. The problem is that now and then I come across songs which are not very well written. For example they might be a bit out of tune since the author did not bother testing anything else than easy difficulty or they may be a bit out of sync because of different versions of the mp3-file. Suggestion: A simple way of fixing songs on-the-fly. Example: Press a special key when playing the song, then use the arrow keys to move the correct lines around. (or shift click) -> means move the line further ahead (to a later time) <- means move earlier ^ means change the correct frequency higher v means change the correct frequency lower If this can be done without stopping the song it would also be a great improvement! Then the audience will not notice that anything changed. When you exit the game mode the user interface should ask if you want to save the changes. Alternative suggestion: If this is too difficult to do I would like a way to "tag" songs with "broken". item.title: #162 Challenge Mode options
item.detail: When choosing the number of players and games in the Challenge Mode people should be able to decide the number of games each player should play and not the total number of games, otherwise it would take too long to play with large groups of people. For example: right now if there are 7 people, the total number of games suggested by the game is 30 (I think). Every player is supposed to play against every other player twice (i.e. home and away). But this takes too long! And, furthermore, the number of games is wrong because it should be 42. But if I choose less games, let's say 12 games, the game will mess things up, because it may happen that a player gets to play 5 games and another player only 3! So the first one will have the chance to win more games and get more points.... obviously there's something wrong. It would be better if I could choose the number of games each player should play: let's say I want each player to play 4 games. It doesn't matter that people won't be able to challenge each and every other friend: the important thing is that each player will play exactly 4 games. Ultrastar should then calculate the right number and combination of games that will allow such a thing. It shouldn't be that complicated to code, I think! I've studied the problem from a mathematical point of view and these are the results (you can think of this as a sort of algorith you can use): Let's assume that N = Number of players; G = Number of games each player is going to play; GTOT = Total number og games played. If you want to let each player play 1 time against each and every other player then GTOT = |N-1| and G = (N-1) . If you want to let each player play 2 times (home and away) against each and every other player then GTOT = (2 * |N-1|) and G = (2 X/2) . Note: if GTOT is not an integer it means that it is impossible to have each player play exactly X games. This means that if the number of players is odd, X has to be even. Hope this is going to help! Toz

item.title: #223 Read tags from MP3 files

I have tags for language, country, label, composer, producer, studio, year of publishing, genre, beats per minute etc. It would be really nice if UltraStar could read these tags and use it for grouping the songs. In my opinion UltraStar needs to hold a list somewhere with all the tags that should be written from the mp3 files and should than allow to group the songs for all of these tags. There are also some advanced features possible: - Tags support multiple values which are separated by semicolons. The UltraStar Mp3 tag support should recognize these multi value fields and list such songs in multiple groups - Some values (like label or composer names) may look different but are equal (e.g. Mercury Records, Mecury Recordings, Mecury etc.). The UltraStar Mp3 tag support should support an equality list or could have some kind of algorithm that finds similar values and assign them to the same group

item.title: #179 Using pitch detection to create usfiles
item.detail: Hi, Recently I got an idea: Since you already have pitch detection code, how about using it in reverse way - to create usfiles themselves? You would pick a mp3 file and play it, during playing you would sing and your pitch would be detected and dumped to the text file. It would REALLY shorten time to create a song. Problems: -No lyrics - you would have to put it by hand after recording - but it's like that in midi creation anyway -Figuring out BPM - I would probably assume default value of around 300 and record accordingly -Figuring out gap - I would suggest manually indicationg when gap starts and ends (ie Button "Start recording", "end recording") What do you think? Regards.

item.title: #188 persistant database for faster startup
item.detail: At the moment the startup time if there are a lot of songs (in my case 3945) in the songs folder is by far too slow. Please make the song database persistent. On startup UltraStar Deluxe should assume there were no changes to the songs. Nothing added, nothing removed. It should start with what was there the last time it was closed. The process checking the whole song database should run in the background with an priority low enough to not disturb the normal gameplay. If the user chooses a song it should be checked if this specific song is still on the disk and if so it could be played without problems. If the song is not on the disk anymore USDX should open a simple dialog telling the user his choosen song is missing and therefore removed from the database. I think, this will speed up things a great deal! To minimize the cases this window appears and to reduce the time till newly added songs are found by the background scanning process, song management functions could be incorporated into USDX. A delete function that removes the selected song from database and harddisk. A delete function that allows to choose multiple songs for deletion. An add-songs function that allows the user to import the songs from a certain directory into USDX. If the user uses these functions to add and remove songs USDX will always know which songs are there and which are not, making the scanning process nearly obsolete.
